title: Can you think of a musician or band that went 30+ years without a loss in the quality of their music? - Quora

response.answer_text: A band that has gone 30+ years without a loss in the quality of their music? I immediately thought of these guys when I saw this question: Los Lobos This outstanding band have been together for 47 years. 47 years! Not only have they maintained the quality of their music, they've only gotten better. We've seen them twice. The first time was outdoors in Nashville. The city hosts a free Wednesday evening event called Uptown Mix.The “venue" was nothing more than city owned property near Vanderbilt University - and a stage. Los Lobos played there on August 4, 2004. And we were fortunate enough to be there. About halfway through it started to rain. I've never seen a crowd less bothered by a downpour. We were too busy enjoying the spectacular music. It was as if the rain only added to our enjoyment. I will never forget dancing with the rain that night. It was magic. There are only a handful of musicians or bands we've seen who sound better live than on their studio albums; Steely Dan (seven times; they're my favorite), The Cure (twice), Annie Lennox (twice as well), and Harry Connick Jr (six times) are a few who come to mind. And my beloved Los Lobos are another. The second time we saw them was a dream come true for me. My husband scored four tickets for an intimate show at a place called Bell's Eccentric Cafe in Kalamazoo. . . . and a Meet & Greet with the band, May 25th, 2018. The show did not disappoint. The small venue had outstanding acoustics and the band was in their usual top form. I was in my glory and … well, did I shed a tear or two of happiness throughout the evening? You bet I did. It's all over my face in the pictures below:  ⬆ Left to right: Saxaphonist Steve Berlin, my dear friend Andrea, drummer Enrique “Bugs" Gonzalez, lead guitarist, vocalist, accordionist, violinist David Hidalgo, a tearful and ecstatic me. Where is the other lead guitarist and vocalist Cesar Rosas? The one with the perpetual sunglasses? He was at the bar having a beer with my husband. I got a picture with him but it didn't turn out. I did, however, get him to take off his shades for a minute when I asked him if his sunglasses were prescription. Having been a Certified Optician for 30 years, I'd often wondered. He said, “No, I just like wearing them.“ He took them off and handed them to me as if to say “Here, see? .. No prescription.” A classic Ray Ban. Which I already knew. 😎 But he did sign my DVD Live at the Fillmore 2004 . . . a spectacular performance that I could listen to every day. Especially two songs, Luz De Mi Vida (Light of my Life) and Chains of Love, on which David Hidalgo plays the most mesmerizing and haunting violin solo I've ever heard, give me goosebumps and bring me to tears. They're so beautiful.  ⬆The illegible autograph of the shaded one ..  ⬆ Me and Bugs . . . He was a bit of a flirt. And it wasn't above me to flirt right back. . . .  ⬆Okay, I wasn't going to post this one because, well, it's a terrible picture of me. My friend's husband snapped it before I was ready. But I couldn't leave out bassist Conrad Lozano, the happiest guy I've ever met. Just look at his wonderful smile; it's ever present, even onstage. Another magical evening because of music .. and a band who's aged like fine wine.  ⬆ Me ’n Andrea … After the show the gal who had been at the table next to us came up to me and said “I hope you don't mind me saying this but I really like your top, especially the neckline . . . . It's like a tiara for your tits”! Of course I didn't mind; I thought it was hilarious. And it gave me and Andrea an alliterative running joke .. It's now called my Tit Tiara Top.

30 years? Try 53 years. Boz Scaggs was in the Steve Miller Band 1967–68, contributing to two epic albums, Sailor and Children of the Future. He went solo in 1969 and recorded his first album for Atlantic in Muscle Shoals, AL with Duane Allman.  Scaggs released two albums in 1971, Moments and Boz Scaggs & Band, wherein he wrote most of the songs, but never received much acclaim even though they had radio hits like “We Were Always Sweethearts” (#61) and “Near You” (#96). These albums were followed up by My Time in 1972 which produced the minor hit, “Dinah Flo”. The majority of the songs on these albums were penned by Boz Scaggs. Next came the album Slow Dancer in 1974. While it failed to chart any hits, it received a Gold Record and made it to #81 on the album chart. Many Boz fans consider it his best.  Scaggs had his greatest success with 1976’s Silk Degrees, containing hits like “Lowdown” (#3), “Lido Shuffle” (#11), and “It’s Over” (#38), propelling Scaggs into the popular limelight.  1977 brought us the albums Down Two Then Left (#11), then Middle Man in 1980 (#8), and Other Roads in 1988, each filled with excellent songs and music like “JoJo” (#17) and “Look What You’ve Done to Me” (#14). So we’re 21 years and 10 solo albums into his career and he’s still very relevant on the music scene.  Scaggs took a hiatus from recording while operating a restaurant and a music nightclub in San Francisco. Luckily for us, 1988 brought us Other Roads (#11), 1994’s Some Change, and the unplugged Japanese release, Fade Into Light in 1996.  Scaggs returned to his blues influenced roots with 1997’s Come On Home, followed by a more polished album, Dig, released on 9/11/2001 (an unfortunate coincidence that hampered the album’s success). I heard him say once that he felt Dig was his best work. Scaggs then switched genres to record two albums of jazz standards, But Beautiful in 2003 and Speak Low in 2008. These albums received rave reviews from the jazz community.  In 2013 Scaggs once again returned to his Texas musical roots with the release of Memphis (#17), followed in 2015 with A Fool to Care (#54). These albums are drenched in roots music, and were a critical success. So were now 46 years into his solo career and he’s still going strong. His last release, 2018’s Out of the Blues completed the trilogy of fine blues and R&B albums.  Boz Scaggs still performs about 50 nights a year, and is held in high acclaim by critics and fans alike. After 53 years, Boz continues to reinforce his reputation as one of America’s finest recording and performing artists.

25 - 30 Years: Miles Davis from his start in the Charlie Parker Band released little that was not of merit and the majority was of high quality from 1945 until his temporary retirement in 1975.Saxophonist Art Pepper from 1952 until 1982, although much of the 60s was spent in the Grey Bar Hotel. His return to playing in 1975 produced another 7 years of arguably even higher standards.Thelonious Monk from his ground breaking work starting with Blue Note in 1947 to Prestige & Riverside in the 50s, commercial success with Columbia in the 60s and bowing out in 1971 is just shy at 24 yearsAs is pianist Bill Evans, whose life was dedicated to music from his debut in 1956 to his early death in 1980.King Crimson & Robert FrippPere Ubu few if any duds from 1975 until 2019Frank Zappa30 - 40 Years: Pianist Keith Jarrett since 1968 rarely if ever dips in quality in solo or group releases.Jazz Guitarist Pat Metheny since 1975 has released multiple 5* albums since. Over 40 years. Singer Nina Simone,Guitarist Paco di Lucia50+ Years: Guitarist Jim Hall played with multiple bands including Chico Hamilton, Jimmy Giuffre, Art Farmer, Sonny Rollins and Paul Desmond and solo released nothing but quality throughout his career from 1955 until 2013 - Over 50 years of high standards and quality South African Pianist Abdullah Ibrahim recorded his first album in 1960 and is still playing live. He left South Africa in 1962 due to Apartheid and has excelled as a band leader and solo performer since. A musician of the highest integrity for over 60 years who follows his own musical path integrating the music of his birthplace with jazz traditions that span a century. He is a particularly mesmerising solo performer capable of improvising for over an hour while captivating the audience. Mannenberg Bassist Charlie Haden started out on record in Ornette Coleman’s startling new Jazz Quartet in 1958 until 61, pianist Danny Zeitlin’s in the mid 60s, Keith Jarrett’s band before leading his own Liberation Music Orchestra from 1969. Parallel with this he was a collosus of goodwill throughout his career regularly speaking out against social injustice, racism, facism & apartheid. His own Quartet West band’s work from 1986 into the 90s was yet another highlight. Whether as a band leader, composer, band member or masterful accompanist in a duo setting, he is one of few artists that released no duds in his long eventful career that came to end in 2014 after well over 50 years of quality.Sun RaDuke EllingtonIn the jazz world there are several more too, l like rock but the life long integrity of many jazz musicians is something to behold.

Many rock artists have been active for 30 years or more, like KISS, Aerosmith, Yes, and Van Halen, but they’ve gone through high highs and low lows. Two bands that I first saw together have, in my opinion, maintained a high level of quality across the decades: Rush and Marillion. Most of you will know Rush, and I don’t think I need to explain further. Few of you will know Marillion, beyond maybe their one “hit,” 1985’s “Kayleigh.” However, they’ve put out 19 albums since 1983, 4 with their original lead singer and 15 with their current one. The early stuff was a mix of Pink Floyd, Peter Gabriel-era Genesis and complicated Rush-like lyrics—very “proggy.” The later stuff is more a mix of Floyd, Radiohead, Talk Talk, Coldplay and Muse—more emotional both musically and lyrically. However, their entire catalog features great musicianship, heartfelt lyrics and emotional heft. From the Wikipedia page on the band: In 2007, Stephen Dalton of The Times stated: The band have just released their 14th album, Somewhere Else, which is really rather good. Containing tracks that shimmer like Coldplay, ache like Radiohead and thunder like Muse, it is better than 80 per cent of this month's releases. But you are unlikely to hear Marillion on British radio, read about them in the music press or see them play a major festival. This is largely because Marillion have – how can we put this kindly? – an image problem. Their music is still perceived as bloated, bombastic mullet-haired prog-rock, even by people who have never heard it. In fairness, they did once release an album called Script for a Jester's Tear. But, come on, we all had bad hair days in the 1980s. That pretty much sums it up. Their 2016 album “F.E.A.R.” ranked 22nd on Loudersound’s “50 Best Rock Albums of the 2010s” alongside bands like Metallica, the Black Keys, Halestorm, Ghost, and Foo Fighters. The 50 best rock albums of the 2010s

I was at Heathrow airport waiting for my flight home. I got through security really fast, so I had some time to kill. I walked into a store that was selling CDs, and there it was:  I was excited because I didn’t know Paul Weller, maybe my favorite artist from the punk era, had a new record out. Wild Wood was released almost 20 years after The Jam’s (Weller’s first band) first release. And what a record it was. Listen to the first track, Sunflower:  There’s not a bad track on the whole record. Except for a small down period when he was leading his second band, The Style Council, Weller had been putting great music out for close to twenty years at this point. Listen to this track, Away From The Numbers, off the Jam’s debut record, In The City, in 1976:  Now, over 40 years into his career, Weller is still producing great music. His latest record, 2018’s True Meanings, is another classic. This time the focus is more acoustic. Here’s the first track, The Soul Searchers:  So, for an artist that started out producing punk rock, then moved to soul music, then to roots rock, then to acoustic, Weller has continued growing and changing as an artist. I can’t wait to see what he does next.

There are lots of excellent answers here. I would not argue with the folks who have mentioned Miles Davis, Richard Thompson or Tom Waits… and even though I am a massive fan of both Frank Zappa and King Crimson I would argue that there were periods of time where they were on the top of their games, and perhaps not as much so during the end years. Zappa’s output toward the end of his career was in compilations of concert material from his career and the occasional album of new (forgettable) material. King Crimson, to my mind, has become nothing more than a very special and well-rehearsed tribute band, and if you need proof just look at one of the stops on their upcoming summer tour where they will be playing Wolf Trap National Park just outside of DC, with The Zappa Band as supporting act… them being an ACTUAL tribute band. However, one gentleman who has managed to stay on top of his game is Andy Partridge. With XTC he moved from Angry White Guy Punk into all types of melodic pop, aggro-rock, and a bit of near-prog rock. As a collaborator and solo artist since the demise of XTC he has stayed focused on quality over quantity. That he is not rich and famous is a crime even as two or three of his songs are actually rather well-known. “Dear God” is one that most people have heard, perhaps as a cover by Sarah MacLachlan, or through the saturation on MTV back in the day. “Mayor of Simpleton” and perhaps “The Ballad Of Peter Pumpkinhead” got good play as well. It is interesting for me to note that those who have allowed me to play XTC/Partridge tunes for them have expressed great interest, generally along the lines of “where has this guy been all my life?” Check out his recent collaboration with Robyn Hitchcock to see what I mean. Completely in command of his amazing talents.

RUSH - the power trio from Canada! Let’s try 40+ years… and for a band, that’s a hard number to beat. Keeping a group together, all the same members for that long, can’t even be compared to a solo musician doing the same thing, the difficulties in group dynamics being what they are. Rush was a progressive rock band, composed of Alex Lifeson (guitarist), Geddy Lee (bass, keyboards, vocals) and “the Professor” Neil Peart (drums, lyrics). From 1974 up until just a few years ago, they continued to sell albums and play concerts to ever-increasing fans. Rush had 24 gold, 11 platinum, 3 multi-platinum records, putting them fifth in most consecutive studio albums behind the Beatles, Rolling Stones, Kiss and Aerosmith. Peart was well-known for his exceptional drumming, with fans and critics alike voting him as the greatest rock drummer in many polls. Not only that, but he also wrote the majority of Rush’s lyrics, usually of fantasy, science fiction and libertarian philosophy. In fact, one of their most successful live shows, which was in Rio de Janeiro of 60,000, the Brazilians sang the lyrics to almost all their songs (in english) and in interviews of the concert-goers, they were speaking of how Rush had taught them about freedom and the spirit of man. Here’s a taste of their “Rush in Rio” tour and dvd. The road crew ran into traffic on the way from the last concert and were so late, fans were already filling the stadium, they had no time for a sound check and Rush started the concert cold… and still played flawlessly. RUSH in Rio - Tom Sawyer

That’s quite a subjective question! And I’ll take it to mean an overall decline in quality, since any band of 30+ years will have ups and downs. My vote — but hardly the only candidate — goes to Iron Maiden. They’re in their 45th year, and while they’ve had ups and downs as well as stylistic variations, I don’t know anyone who says their quality has diminished. Someone might not like their music now compared to, say, 1982 — but it’s not because it’s musically worse. It’s just different. If anything, their music is much richer, more complex, and interesting than it was in years past. Their last album (their 15th studio album) was arguably their most ambitious and received huge acclaim. Rush is another. I was less of a fan of their later music, but there was certainly never an overall decline in quality in their 40+ years. Thanks for the A2A! [Answered: Can you think of a musician or band that went 30+ years without a loss in the quality of their music?]

I interpret this question as bands that put out consistently good records and never had any periods were the music was bad or there was an obvious loss of quality. For any musician or band to go 30+ years and not have at least one stinker is pretty incredible. Just to give some perspective even bands like The Rolling Stones, The Who, Aerosmith, Elton John had periods where their music fell off. Musicians: Keith Jarrett, McCoy Tyner, Dwight Yoakam Pat Metheny: Not only has his music quality consistently ranged from really good to incredible, he’s also done it while trying different styles of music, playing different instruments and playing on an array of projects as a guest. Bands: Radiohead, Steely Dan, Beastie Boys, Van Halen Rush: They don’t have a bad record (and I’m not saying this because they are my favorite band). I’m being pretty objective having heard all their albums. They’ve been very consistent especially for band thats released as many records as they have and tried different styles & different sounds. Many vary in quality but none are bad. Some fans might hate certain records or time periods but overall they have been very consistent. They finished out their career with a couple of strong records.

It really depends on what you consider “quality”. Quality of their compositions? Technical skills? Recordings or live? In the very broad rock genre, it’s difficult -to be fair for a lot of musicians - to hit the same high notes at 55 or 65 years old that they did in the 80s. It’s also really hard to stay relevant. As far as bands go, my choices are: Rush - who did an amazing job with the same lineup for so many years and very little decline in technical skills. You can hear the difference in Geddy’s voice over the years but even so he is really an A-lister. Alex sounds a wee bit cleaner on earlier live performances but again they are crazy good. I would say I didn’t really like the songwriting after the mid-90s though.The Cure. Haven’t seen them lately, but great for many years.Solo: Joe Satriani. It’s not quite fair to compare a solo musician to bands. But neither his playing nor songwriting have declined for over 30 years.

I started listening to Mose Allison in 1965, and kept listening to his stuff from that era during the ensuing decades. Did you know the Who’s hit “Young Man Blues” was actually written by Mose? Imagine my pleasure at hearing he was doing a gig at a club in Germantown. I went there and was waiting at the ticket table when this little old guy came by and tripped on my heel, and it was Mose! He said “Excuse me” and all I could say was “Sure, any time!” I found a seat in the front row (this was a small club, I mean really small), and noticed that his backup players included a string bass player I had played with in Jenkintown, so I was chatting with him when Mose came in and sat down at a keyboard so close to my seat I could practically reach out and touch him. He started the set with no long intro, just told the backups “We’ll start with #17 please”, and they all launched into #17 in his playbook, whatever that was. Took the applause, then said “#4” and they played #4. Then he said “Blues in E” and they played blues in E. And he did that the whole set. Less than a minute between tunes, and little or no intro for any of them. And he kept it up for 90 minutes. And most of the material was new to me; he had been composing new stuff during the intervening 50 years. I left after the first show, but he had a whole second set to play that night. What a powerhouse. That was in 2012 I think, so he must have been 85. Died in 2016.

Not a lot of rock bands have maintained that level of consistency. But I’d say that King Crimson and Frank Zappa kept up an interesting level of quality. Not always to all taste but the music was usually pretty good. The Magnetic Fields have had a pretty solid career at this point but not sure if it’s up to 30 years yet. Lots of jazz musicians kept their relevancy for that period of time. A few have already mentioned Miles Davis and Thelonious Monk, two of the most important. I’d put Charles Mingus in there, as well, as likely the superior composer to the two in many ways. I think the all-time king of long-term quality is Duke Ellington. His late 1920s work was sterling and well-composed jazz and he continually evolved throughout his career, staying on or sometimes predicting trends. No other swing artist from his period, for example, put out an album as exploratory and engaging as “The Money Jungle,” which featured the incredible contributions of Mingus on bass and Max Roach on drums.

JRD’s vote would be for Black Sabbath. Back when heavy metal was begotten, Sabbath was considered pioneers of the new genre. Within less than a decade, they paved the way for ‘shock rock’, opening doors for Alice Cooper, Bloodrock, David Bowie, the Velvet Underground and Iggy and the Stooges. This was the segue into the Punk Revolution. Black Sabbath was accused of being Satanist, which was as absurd as David Bowie being confirmed as a Martian. Only Ozzy Osbourne’s mental disorders sent him over the edge often enough to have him discharged from the band. The Oz began touring solo and Sabbath went through a prolonged episode of lineup changes. Yet, decades later, they reformed in their mid-life and literally did not skip a beat. Tony Iommi has to be credited as one of the greatest guitarists in rock history. His immortal riffs helped define the genre and carve a niche for Black Sabbath. Yet Ozzy’s stage persona and psycho lyrics created an unforgettable musical concept. They played a farewell gig after three decades, and it was a trip back through time that proved they had passed the test.

Richard Thompson. He's gone 50 years without a loss in quality in his legendary guitar playing, songwriting, or singing. and continues to record and perform. He continues to be creative, inventive, and a captivating performer. You can add to that King Crimson (whose tours over the last few years have been astounding), Jeff Beck, whose late work, IMHO, shows a performer at the peak of his powers, Bill Frisell, June Tabor, Brian Eno, David Byrne and Elvis Costello. There are others. I think it also important to distinguish between continued quality and continued popularity and market success. They rarely go hand in hand.

Jackson Browne has been making compelling music since the early 1970s, and continues to do so today. Rush made many albums and toured for 40 years, always with creativity, excellence, and professionalism, until their final tour (RIP Neil Peart). I have to bring up the case of David Crosby, who, in his 70s, has made 5 compelling albums and written some of the most meaningful songs of his life, and backed them up with solid live work. Ian Anderson continues to tour with Jethro Tull and on his own, record, and, despite the fact that he can’t play the flute on one leg anymore, is well worth your time and ticket money. Earth, Wind, and Fire still tour, and will still get you up and dancing in the aisles. Just because the classic rockers that are left don’t get airplay anymore does not mean they aren’t recording quality material or touring.

Easily. I can tell you a band that went over 40 years, produced 14 studio albums, plus over half a dozen live albums. They got BETTER with every album. Had two key members die along the way (from medical reasons, not self-abuse). They finally hung up their guns (as a band) last fall because the primary songwriter and producer could no longer tour. I’ve seen so many top-rung bands perform since the mid-60s. These guys were the best live band on the planet! Which band? TOTO. If all you’ve heard is the few hit singles they released, you’ve never heard TOTO.

I can think of several, Tangerine Dream, started in 1969, still going strong even after their founder died, Kraftwerk, same thing, still going and touring, Manfred Mann's Earth Band, still going strong, Depeche Mode, going strong, Yes, rotating door of members but still making great music, Rick Wakeman, never stopped, Procol Harum, 1967, still going strong, I believe Tony Bennett is still recording and performing. Probably a few more, these are the ones I can think of off the top of my head.

The first artist that comes to mind is Bob Dylan. From the early 60s until now he has steadily released good albums. There are a few exceptions. In a move that many people believe was an act of revenge Colombia released an album of covers called Dylan when he temporarily left them for another label. And then there’s the one-two punch of Knocked Out and Loaded and Down In the Groove, but even they had a couple of gems on them. But overall an impressive body of work spanning over 50 years.

Jeff Beck’s music and playing are as good as ever. His newer music is still as innovative and brilliant as what he was doing 30 and even 50 years ago, and his playing is just as inventive and amazing as it’s ever been, with him still trying new things and exploring new styles. He’s shown no loss of quality over the decades and has perhaps even gotten better in some ways.

I suppose itdepends on how their “quality” is defined: Do you mean that their popularity hasn't waned too much? (ie because they are still popular, must mean their quality is still good) Or that they are churning out the same formulaic material without any real variety of style? (ie the no change of style means no change in quality) And if you are asking for examples of artists/bands, then one man's meat is another man's poison, as the saying goes, because there will always be vast differences of opinion - some very strong - so you'll get little in the way of any consensus…..

Todd Rundgren!!! Has been rocking the last 50+ years and still kills it to this day!!! From the Nazz to solo work to Utopia to today. Producer extraordinaire (XTC, NYDolls, Meat Loaf, Badfinger, Grand Funk RR, many others) still fresh and current, and NEVER fails to entertain! Not sure if the shows scheduled for this May are going to happen, but he's always doing something musical that can put a smile on the face of an aging musicial curmudgeon such as I. If you haven't listened, give him a try!

I’m gonna go with a combination of the two, in the form of Mark E. Smith of The Fall. I stumbled into a copy of their first record at a flea market, in the late 70s, and fell in love with their punk ass attitude. He fired something like 40 different band members over the years, and in the next 4 decades knocked out about 35 full length albums. He passed away in 2019, and while I hardly know all their work, right up til the end he was kicking ass and taking no shit, and making great stuff for right now and forever. A true original.

My vote is for a group of young men that started touring in the late 60's with a unique style of music and lyrics that would become known as symphonic rock… The last time I saw the Moody Blues live was 2016, and they were still as crisp as ever to a SOLD OUT concert . Yup… my vote is for The Moody Blues.

Greg Dulli of the Afghan Whigs is still making music in 2020 every bit as good as, if not better than, any of his band’s music in the early 90s. Through his years with the Twilight Singers, then the reforming of the Afghan Whigs for two albums in 2014 and 2017, I’m never disappointed in anything this guy does. (Ok, I wasn’t in love with his “Gutter Twins” collaboration with Mark Lanegan.) His most recent 2020 solo album is rock solid as well.

Van Morrison. Been recording since the early 60s—that’s almost sixty years now—and while he’s certainly had better and worse records, and better and worse periods, his best is still the best. His most recent CD, Three Chords and the Truth, has wonderful things on it.

I was certain someone else must have mentioned it, but I don’t see his name on here anywhere! “Weird Al” Yankovic and his band have not only not had a loss in quality, they have gotten better. Lots better! And they were damn good when they started! Measured by sales, awards, or respect of peers, they have risen in every category.

I’d have to say Radiohead. Others have posted bands with longevity. That in itself is a mark of greatness. But most of them have released basically the same album over 30 years. Can you really tell each Rolling Stones album from the other? Another answer mentions some of the Jazz greats, they innovated but didn’t get widespread recognition. Radiohead have changed and evolved unlike any other popular band out there. Yeah, others have evolved more, and others have maintained more followers. But to be quite flippant and controversial, Coldplay have maintained a 25 year career copying a couple of their early songs.

Wire, The Bevis Frond, Dinosaur Jr. All three bands have been around for at least 35 years. (Wire for nearly 45.) All of them are making new music now that is at least as good as they were in the beginning, often better.

The late great Oscar Peterson. Of course it wasn’t the same after the stroke, but the awesomeness lasted well beyond 30 years. People who understand the stuff have told me it’s Art Tatum, then Oscar Peterson, and then everybody else. Lots of good accompaniments with Ella. (My pick, based on my limited exposure is the relatively recent “Side by Side” album with Itzhak Perlman.)

Damon Albarn. His band Blur’s first single came out in 1990, and they were one of the biggest UK bands of that decade. Then in 2000, his new band Gorillaz released their first single, and they’ve been going strong ever since. He’s quite prolific, and has also released a solo album, produced others, made two albums under the moniker The Good, the Bad & the Queen, as well as other projects (Africa Express; Rocket Juice & the Moon).
Tom Waits.

Cardiacs. Changed in lineup and in sound over the years but always quirky, interesting and irreverant. Sadly brought to a halt some years ago by their main man’s tragic illness. Try this  or this  Great fun.

Nick Cave. He’s never put out a duff album. Some weren’t quite as good as others but he’s never released anything that’s categorically bad. People claim Nocturama is a low point but seriously? Babe, I’m On Fire is just epic.

There are lots of musicians in that category. Two of my favorite bands that come to my mind immediately are: Dream Theater  and Stryper  Both have had ups and downs, but continue to make great music and put on great shows after 30+ years.
Several. Steely Dan, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, The Rolling Stones, Pink Floyd, Styx, Journey, Rush, AC/DC, Eric Clapton are just a few.

In rock - it’s Nick Cave, Nick Cave, Nick Cave! best and most vital career after crossing the 35 years old mark in rock history - other acts have definitely had great efforts post 35, but Cave just keeps doing it and doing it and doing it.

Leonid Vorobyev from Leonid and Friends currently recording and touring… seen here playing bass…Dimitri Czapkiewicz's post in Leonid and Friends & FANS Most artist change or loose something… or change styles  Dimitri Czapkiewicz thanks for looking
Steely Dan! From Can't Buy A Thrill in 1972 all the way to Everything Must Go in 2006 they released numerous albums of high quality.
They Might Be Giants have been at it since the mid 80’s If anything they keep getting better. Not a bad album in the bunch.
Iron Maiden, Judas Priest, Brian Setzer/Stray Cats, Pearl Jam, U2.
SLAAAAAYERRRRR!!!
BOB DYLAN
